Award.AwardTitle: NRI: US National Robotics Roadmap Update

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal will support travel by robotics researchers to two workshops to update the National Robotics Roadmap. The Roadmap was first developed in 2008-2009 and helped contribute to the establishment of the National Robotics Initiative. The Roadmap was subsequently updated in 2012-2013. Much has happened in the field of robotics in the past four years, and it is prudent to update the Roadmap, once again. The two-day workshops, to be held at Oregon State University and Georgia Institute of Technology, will bring together a diverse group of US robotics researchers to discuss issues related to the societal drivers and technical challenges ahead for robotics. The outcome will be a publically available report on the future of robotics, which may serve to help formulate a national strategy for robotics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intiial US robotics roadmap was sponsored by the Computing Community  Consortium and released May 2009. A second update was released October 2013. The present update was to be released by the end of the administration to provide guidance as a new administration takes office. 

The objective of this project was an update to the National Robotics Roadmap. The effort involved two workshops - one on the west coast in Portland, OR and another in Atlanta, GA. The workshops includes researchers from industry and academia. 

The roadmap includes updates to the topical areas of manufacturing, service, healthcare, defense and space robotics. For each area the present state of the art is summarized, the main societal challenges are described, and the key research challenges with expected results in a 5, 10 and 15-year perspective are presented. The updated roadmap also has two new sections. One about the need for common infrastrcutrue and another discusses ethical, legal and societal implications of robotics technology. 

The roadmap was edited by a small group of individuals and synthesized by the PI into a single report. The report was presented to the government's Interagency Working Group on Robotics, which was established with the assistance of OSTP and NITRD. The report was presented to the group on November 7, 2016. The report has later been presented to a number of constituents such as the Robotics Industry Association (RIA), the NSF National Robotics Program (NRI) Principal Investogators, and a numerous conferences and workshops to make the study findings availble to as broad an audience as possible.
